name: Network analysis issues for a public Internet
description:
While initially conceived as a dedicated communications facility for
the United States federal government, today's Internet aggregates
traffic from among a far wider set of constituencies. Pooling resources
of so many constituents into a massively interconnected environment
raises the issue of resource and cost allocation. In this paper we
describe the importance of network analysis in support of resource
attribution and evaluate a number of examples. We offer evidence to
support our hypothesis that, in the face of the current evolution of
global information infrastructure, vastly expanding both in ubiquity
and sophistication of applications, Internet policy considerations and
network analysis must begin to interact in ways not previously
recognized or implemented. In particular, as the scale of, access to,
and commercialization of the Internet broadens, cost allocation among
(even globally) shared resources will require the development of new
accounting and billing models to accommodate the wide range of players
and services.
